vis-1.title: Color Reliance
vis-1.content: Did you know? Color alone should not be used to convey meaning. Use icons, text labels, or patterns alongside color indicators to ensure users with color blindness can understand the status.

vis-2.title: Text Contrast
vis-2.content: Body text should have a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 against its background. Large text (bold 18pt+ or regular 24pt+) needs a ratio of 3:1.

vis-3.title: Focus Indicators
vis-3.content: All interactive elements must have a visible focus indicator. Never remove the outline style with CSS unless you replace it with a highly visible custom style.

vis-4.title: Zoom and Scaling
vis-4.content: Users should be able to zoom in up to 200% without loss of content or functionality. Avoid disabling viewport zooming in your meta tags.

vis-5.title: Link Identification
vis-5.content: Links within text blocks should be identifiable by more than just color. Underlines are the most common and understood way to distinguish links.

key-1.title: Keyboard Traps
key-1.content: Ensure users can navigate into and out of all interactive elements using only a keyboard. Custom modals are common places where keyboard focus can get stuck.

key-2.title: Logical Tab Order
key-2.content: The tab order should follow the visual reading order of the page. Avoid using positive tabindex values (> 0) as they can disrupt the natural flow.

key-3.title: Skip Links
key-3.content: Provide a 'Skip to Main Content' link at the top of the page. This allows keyboard and screen reader users to bypass repetitive navigation menus.

key-4.title: Interactive Elements
key-4.content: Anything that looks clickable must be clickable with a keyboard. If you use a <div> as a button, you must add role='button' and tabindex='0' and handle Enter/Space keys.

sr-1.title: Alternative Text
sr-1.content: Alt text should describe the purpose of the image, not just its appearance. If an image is purely decorative, use an empty alt attribute (alt="").

sr-2.title: Heading Structure
sr-2.content: Use headings (H1-H6) to create a logical outline of your content. Don't skip heading levels (e.g., H1 to H3) as screen reader users rely on them for navigation.

sr-3.title: Meaningful Link Text
sr-3.content: Link text should make sense on its own. Avoid 'Click here' or 'Read more'. Instead, use descriptive text like 'Read more about Accessibility'.

sr-4.title: Landmarks
sr-4.content: Use HTML5 semantic regions like <main>, <nav>, <header>, and <footer>. These are automatically recognized as landmarks by screen readers.

sr-5.title: Language Attribute
sr-5.content: Always set the <html lang="en"> attribute. This ensures screen readers pronounce the content correctly using the appropriate accent and rules.

form-1.title: Visible Labels
form-1.content: Every form input needs a permanently visible label. Placeholders are not a substitute for labels, as they disappear when the user starts typing.

form-2.title: Error Identification
form-2.content: When a form error occurs, identify the error clearly in text and programmatically associate the error message with the input field using aria-describedby.

form-3.title: Autocomplete Attributes
form-3.content: Use the autocomplete attribute on input fields to help users fill out forms faster. This is especially helpful for people with cognitive disabilities.

form-4.title: Grouping Controls
form-4.content: Related form controls, like radio buttons or checkboxes, should be grouped using <fieldset> and <legend> to provide context.

gen-1.title: Motion Sensitivity
gen-1.content: Provide a mechanism to pause, stop, or hide any auto-playing content or animations. Respect the 'prefers-reduced-motion' media query.

gen-2.title: Simple Language
gen-2.content: Write clearly and simply. Avoid jargon and complex sentence structures. This benefits users with cognitive disabilities and non-native speakers.

gen-3.title: Consistent Navigation
gen-3.content: Keep navigation mechanisms consistent across your site. Users shouldn't have to relearn how to navigate on every new page.

gen-4.title: Target Size
gen-4.content: Touch targets should be at least 44x44 CSS pixels (or 24x24 in WCAG 2.2) to ensure they are easily tappable on mobile devices.

mag-1.title: Automated vs Manual
mag-1.content: Automated tools only catch about 30-50% of accessibility issues. Manual testing with keyboard and screen readers is essential for full compliance.

mag-2.title: Acceptance Criteria
mag-2.content: Include accessibility checks in your definition of done (DoD). Accessibility should be considered during design and development, not just at the end.

mag-3.title: Headings Map
mag-3.content: Use a browser extension like 'HeadingsMap' to visualize your document/page structure. The outline should look like a table of contents.

mag-4.title: Screen Reader on Mobile
mag-4.content: Test on real mobile devices using VoiceOver (iOS) or TalkBack (Android). Emulators often don't accurately reflect mobile screen reader behavior.

doc-1.title: PDF Accessibility
doc-1.content: PDFs need tags to be accessible. A tagged PDF contains a hidden layer of structure that screen readers use to navigate the document.

doc-2.title: Table Headers
doc-2.content: Data tables must have header cells (<th>) identified. Use scope='col' or scope='row' to association data cells with their headers explicitly.

dev-1.title: Linter Integration
dev-1.content: Use eslint-plugin-jsx-a11y to catch accessibility errors while you code. It can identify missing alt text, invalid aria roles, and more.

mag-5.title: Keyboard Traps & Regions
mag-5.content: Ensure custom widgets (like complex grids or maps) allow keyboard escape. Users should never get stuck in a component without a way to exit.

wai-1.title: Label in Name
wai-1.content: For buttons with text and icons, ensure the visible text matches the accessible name (aria-label). Speech recognition users rely on saying exactly what they see.

wai-2.title: Status Messages
wai-2.content: Use role='status' or aria-live='polite' for dynamic updates (like 'Search results updated') so screen readers announce them without moving focus.

mob-2.title: Orientation
mob-2.content: Don't lock screen orientation. Apps must work in both portrait and landscape modes, as some users have devices fixed to wheelchairs.

vis-6.title: Reflow (400% Zoom)
vis-6.content: Test your site at 400% zoom (1280px width). Content should reflow into a single column without horizontal scrolling, which is difficult for low-vision users.

tool-2.title: WAVE Tool
tool-2.content: WAVE is a browser extension that visualizes accessibility issues directly on your page. It's excellent for spotting heading structure and contrast errors.

tool-3.title: axe DevTools
tool-3.content: axe DevTools runs in your browser console and catches ~50% of issues automatically. It's a standard tool for developers to catch syntax errors early.

tool-4.title: Colour Contrast Analyser
tool-4.content: The TPGi Colour Contrast Analyser (CCA) includes an eyedropper to test contrast on non-web files like PDFs or Figma designs.

contrastCheckerTool.title: Contrast Checker
contrastCheckerTool.description: Check if your color combination meets WCAG accessibility standards.
